PURSUANT TO A 1996 AGREEMENT BETWEEN A NEW YORK UNIVERSITY AFFILIATED ENTITY AND PROFESSOR RICHARD STEWART, PROFESSOR STEWART WAS PROVIDED WITH AN OPTION TO PURCHASE THE TOWNHOUSE OWNED BY THE AFFILIATED ENTITY IN WHICH HE RESIDED AND IN WHICH THE CENTER ON ENVIRONMENTAL AND LAND USE LAW OF WHICH HE WAS THE DIRECTOR WAS LOCATED, WITH THE PURCHASE PRICE ESTABLISHED ACCORDING TO A FORMULA IN THE AGREEMENT. IN 2002, THE TOWNHOUSE AND THE AGREEMENT WITH PROFESSOR STEWART SETTING THE PURCHASE PRICE FOR THE OPTION WERE TRANSFERRED BY THE AFFILIATED ENTITY TO THE UNIVERSITY. PROFESSOR STEWART RESIDED IN THE TOWNHOUSE AND RAN THE CENTER FROM THE TOWNHOUSE UNTIL 2017 WHEN HE ASSIGNED HIS OPTION TO A THIRD PARTY WHO PURCHASED THE TOWNHOUSE IN 2017. IN THAT SALE, THE UNIVERSITY RECEIVED THE AMOUNT ESTABLISHED UNDER THE AGREEMENT FORMULA, AND PROFESSOR STEWART RECEIVED THE BALANCE OF THE PROCEEDS OF THE SALE, WHICH WERE PAID TO HIM NET OF TAX WITHHOLDINGS. THE UNIVERSITY WAS FOUNDED BY THE SISTERS OF MERCY AND HAS EMPLOYEES WHO ARE AFFILIATED WITH THIS RELIGIOUS ORDER. BECAUSE OF THE NATURE OF THE ORDER AND THE POVERTY VOWS TAKEN BY SISTERS LISTED ON FORM 990, PART VII, W-2 EARNINGS ARE NOT REPORTED AS THESE EMPLOYEES ARE NOT DIRECTLY TAXABLE DUE TO RELIGIOUS AFFILIATION. RATHER, THEIR COMPENSATION IS MADE PAYABLE PRIMARILY TO THE SISTERS OF MERCY AND IT IS THE ORDER THAT DETERMINES WHAT PORTION THE EMPLOYEES WILL RECEIVE. TOTAL COMPENSATION TO THE SISTERS OF MERCY TOTALED $622,109 FOR THE 2017 CALENDAR YEAR OF WHICH THE PRESIDENT AND CHANCELLOR WERE A PART OF.

TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: THE COLLEGE ONLY PAYS THE TRAVEL EXPENSES OF THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE IF THE PURPOSE OF HER TRIP IS RELATED TO COLLEGE BUSINESS. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE: THE COLLEGE'S PRESIDENT AND THE COLLEGE'S VICE PRESIDENT FOR STUDENT AFFAIRS ARE PROVIDED WITH HOUSES AS CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT. THE HOUSES ARE USED FOR BOTH BUSINESS AND PERSONAL PURPOSES. HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES ARE ALSO PROVIDED. PERSONAL SERVICES: THE COLLEGE PAYS FOR THE PRESIDENT'S TAX PREPARATION AND ESTATE PLANNING. TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS: ELIGIBLE COLLEGE EMPLOYEES RECEIVE AN ANNUAL RETIREMENT PLAN CONTRIBUTION FROM THE COLLEGE EQUAL TO 10% OF ELIGIBLE SALARY, SUBJECT TO IRS ANNUAL LIMITATIONS. BECAUSE THE PRESIDENT'S COMPENSATION TRIGGERS THE LIMITATION EFFECT, THE COLLEGE SUPPLEMENTS THE PRESIDENT'S ANNUAL CASH COMPENSATION WITH AN AMOUNT THAT BRINGS THE RETIREMENT PLAN CONTRIBUTION TO THE LEVEL OF OTHER PARTICIPANTS IN THE PLAN. THE COLLEGE OFFSETS THE INCOME TAX BURDEN OF THIS ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION BY GROSSING UP THE WAGES FOR THE YEAR. THIS ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION IS REPORTED ON THE EMPLOYEE'S W-2. THE COLLEGE SUPPLEMENTS THE LIFE INSURANCE OFFERED THROUGH ITS BENEFIT PLANS WITH AN ADDITIONAL POLICY FOR THE PRESIDENT OF THE COLLEGE. THE PRESIDENT PAYS THE ANNUAL PREMIUM FOR THE POLICY AND IS REIMBURSED BY THE COLLEGE. UNDER IRS RULES, SUCH PAYMENT MUST BE REPORTED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO THE EMPLOYEE. THE COLLEGE OFFSETS THE INCOME TAX BURDEN OF THIS COMPENSATION BY GROSSING UP THE WAGES FOR THE YEAR. THIS ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION IS REPORTED ON THE EMPLOYEE'S W-2.

THE COLLEGE'S PRESIDENT IS THE SOLE PARTICIPANT IN TWO NONQUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLANS. THE COLLEGE PLACED $100,000 IN THE FIRST PLAN DURING THE YEAR COVERED BY THIS REPORT. CERTAIN TIME-IN-SERVICE AND PERFORMANCE REQUIREMENTS MUST BE MET FOR THE PRESIDENT TO RECEIVE THIS PLAN'S ASSETS. THE COLLEGE PLACED $18,000 IN THE SECOND PLAN DURING THE YEAR. THIS PLAN HAS NO TIME-IN-SERVICE OR PERFORMANCE REQUIREMENTS TO RECEIVE THE PLAN'S ASSETS.

ExplntnTxt: THE MIDWESTERN UNIVERSITY SUPPLEMENTAL EXECUTIVE RETIREMENT PLAN II (THE"PLAN"), EFFECTIVE JUNE 30, 2017, HAS BEEN ESTABLISHED FOR THE BENEFIT OF DR. KATHLEEN GOEPPINGER, THE PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER ("CEO") OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE PLAN IS INTENDED TO PROVIDE THE CEO WITH A TARGET RETIREMENT BENEFIT FOR HER SERVICE WITH MWU FOR THE PERIOD BEGINNING ON HER 65TH BIRTHDAY AND ENDING ON HER 75TH BIRTHDAY BASED UPON HER AVERAGE COMPENSATION FOR THE THREE CONSECUTIVE CALENDAR YEARS OF THIS PERIOD DURING WHICH HER COMPENSATION IS THE HIGHEST, WITH A LEVEL OF ANNUAL ACCRUALS APPROXIMATING 82.5% OF MARKET, AND OFFSETS BY OTHER RETIREMENT PLANS. THE BENEFIT VESTS AND WILL BE PAID IN TWO INSTALLMENTS FOLLOWING THE CEO'S 70TH AND 75TH BIRTHDAYS RESPECTIVELY, EACH DETERMINED WITH APPROPRIATE PROJECTIONS, CALCULATIONS AND RE-CALCULATIONS AS REQUIRED. THE CONSULTING FIRM OF KORN FERRY HAY GROUP WAS RETAINED TO CONSTRUCT A PROPOSAL TO ESTABLISH THE PLAN AND TO REVIEW THE PRESIDENT AND CEO 'S TOTAL COMPENSATION, THE RESULTS OF WHICH WERE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY BOTH THE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES AND THE FULL BOARD OF TRUSTEES. AS OF DECEMBER 31, 2017, $911,002 HAD BEEN ACCRUED BY UNIVERSITY FOR THE PROVISION OF RETIREMENT BENEFITS UNDER THE PLAN. THIS AMOUNT IS REPORTED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN C. IN FEBRUARY OF 2018, THE FIRST INSTALLMENT PAYABLE UNDER THE PLAN OF $836,000 WAS PAID TO DR. GOEPPINGER.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: COMPENSATION CONTINGENT UPON THE REVENUES OF THE ORGANIZATION
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 5A The Compensation Committee implemented a Compensation Philosophy for the officers of the organization through the application of the following considerations: * Base salary will be set so that the targeted positioning of an Officer is the 50th percentile of the target market for each position. Base salary for an individual Officer relative to the target market pay will be set by the President based on the individual's unique background, experiences, personal skills and abilities (including creativity, growth-orientation and discipline) as well as based on the business challenges facing the Organization which require the use of such attributes or skills. * Annual incentive compensation, if any, will be delivered according to a guideline that approximates the market 75th percentile total cash compensation for commensurate performance. The Committee has the discretion to deliver annual incentives above or below the 75th percentile based on individual circumstances and performance conditions. The aim of annual incentives is to drive and reward consistent improvement in performance. Goals to achieve an incentive payout include, but are not limited to, targets at different levels for total revenues of the organization.

TAX INDEMNIFICATION: STANDARD POLICY FOR ALL SUTTER HEALTH EMPLOYEES IS THAT NON-CASH GIFTS AND AWARDS ARE GROSSED-UP FOR TAX PURPOSES. THE AMOUNT OF THE GROSS-UP IS ADDED TO THE EMPLOYEE'S WAGES AND TAXED ACCORDINGLY.

SUPPLEMENTAL COMPENSATION INFORMATION: THE CEO OF THIS ORGANIZATION BEGAN THE YEAR AS AN EMPLOYEE OF SUTTER HEALTH, A RELATED TAX-EXEMPT ORGANIZATION. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE SUTTER HEALTH BOARD OF DIRECTORS RETAINS ULTIMATE DISCRETIONARY AUTHORITY OVER ALL ELEMENTS OF COMPENSATION TO ASSURE THAT ORGANIZATIONAL PURPOSES ARE APPROPRIATELY BEING SERVED. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE USES CREDIBLE DATA SOURCES AND MAINTAINS AN OBJECTIVE "ARMS LENGTH" DECISION-MAKING PROCESS, ENSURING THE INTEGRITY OF SUTTERS EXECUTIVE PROGRAMS AND CONSISTENCY WITH THE ORGANIZATIONS OVERALL MISSION. SEE SCHEDULE O NARRATIVE FOR PART VI, LINE 15 FOR A FULL DESCRIPTION OF THE COMPENSATION APPROVAL PROCESS COMPLETED BY SUTTER HEALTH.

NONQUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN: THE PURPOSE OF THE NONQUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN IS TO PROVIDE SUTTER HEALTH EXECUTIVES WITH A COMPETITIVE RETIREMENT BENEFIT CONSISTENT WITH SUTTER HEALTH'S OVERALL COMPENSATION PHILOSOPHY FOR ALL EMPLOYEES. CONTRIBUTIONS ARE DESIGNED TAKING INTO CONSIDERATION LOST RETIREMENT BENEFITS THAT WOULD OTHERWISE BE OBTAINED THROUGH THE QUALIFIED PENSION PLAN. SUTTER'S PLANS ARE DESIGNED CONSISTENT WITH COMPETITIVE INDUSTRY PRACTICES. THE RETIREMENT PLAN FOR SUTTER HEALTH EMPLOYEES IS A COMBINATION OF 403(B) EMPLOYER MATCH CONTRIBUTIONS AND QUALIFIED PENSION PLAN BENEFITS. SUTTER HEALTH EXECUTIVES ARE GENERALLY INELIGIBLE FOR EMPLOYER MATCH CONTRIBUTIONS. TO ENSURE A COMPETITIVE RETIREMENT BENEFIT AND TO ADDRESS THE SHORTFALLS DESCRIBED ABOVE, SUTTER HEALTH MAKES AN ANNUAL CONTRIBUTION TO A NON-QUALIFIED 457(F) PLAN FOR ITS EXECUTIVES. THE FORMULA HAS TWO PARTS: (1) 4% TO 7% OF BASE SALARY (COMMENSURATE WITH MANAGEMENT LEVEL), PLUS (2) A CONTRIBUTION STARTING AT 5% (BASED UPON TENURE) FOR ELIGIBLE EARNINGS BEYOND THE IRS DEFINITION OF INCLUDIBLE COMPENSATION ("PENSION PAY CAP"). THE LATTER OF WHICH IS DESIGNED TO HELP RESTORE LOST PENSION BENEFITS FORFEITED UNDER THE QUALIFIED PENSION PLAN FOR EARNINGS OVER THE PENSION PAY CAP LIMIT. CONTRIBUTIONS ARE ALSO MADE FOR A SMALL GROUP OF SENIOR LEVEL EXECUTIVES WHOSE ESTIMATED RETIREMENT BENEFIT (SOCIAL SECURITY PLUS QUALIFIED PLAN BENEFITS PLUS 457F) FALLS BELOW 50% - 65% OF FINAL 4-YEAR AVERAGE BASE SALARY WHEN RETIRING AT AGE 65 WITH 22.5 YEARS OF SERVICE. TARGET BENEFIT LEVELS ARE DISCOUNTED FOR YEARS OF SERVICE LESS THAN 22.5 AT AGE 65. UNLIKE SUTTER HEALTH'S QUALIFIED PENSION PLAN WHERE EMPLOYEE BENEFITS ARE GUARANTEED (I.E., A DEFINED BENEFIT), SUTTER'S NON-QUALIFIED PLAN BENEFITS ARE NOT GUARANTEED BY SUTTER HEALTH. INVESTMENT RISK IS BORNE BY PARTICIPANTS AND BENEFITS ARE NOT PROTECTED SHOULD SUTTER HEALTH BECOME INSOLVENT. THE FOLLOWING INDIVIDUALS RECEIVED 457(F) NON-QUALIFIED PAYMENTS DURING THE YEAR: JEFF GERARD - $127,706

NON-FIXED PAYMENTS: SPOT AWARDS ARE INFREQUENTLY USED TO REWARD EMPLOYEES. THERE ARE NO SPECIFIC GUIDELINES FOR THE AMOUNT OF THE SPOT AWARD BUT THE AMOUNT TENDS TO NOT EXCEED 5% TO 10% OF GROSS ANNUAL SALARY. ANNUAL INCENTIVE PLAN (AIP) THE PURPOSE OF THE PLAN IS TO FOCUS EXECUTIVES ON SPECIFIC, SHORTER-TERM GOALS THAT ARE CRITICAL TO THE ACHIEVEMENT OF AFFILIATE, OPERATING UNIT AND SYSTEM-WIDE OBJECTIVES THAT DRIVE OVERALL ORGANIZATION PERFORMANCE. A PORTION OF THE PLAN AWARD IS DISCRETIONARY IN THAT THE SUPERVISOR MAY ADD UP TO 5% TO THE AWARD PROVIDED THE TOTAL AWARD (FORMULA PORTION PLUS DISCRETIONARY) DOES NOT EXCEED THE MAXIMUM ESTABLISHED FOR ANY GIVEN EXECUTIVE. LONG TERM PERFORMANCE PLANS SUTTER HEALTH ALSO EMPLOYS A LONG TERM PERFORMANCE PLAN WHICH IS DESIGNED TO FOCUS ON LONGER TERM STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES OF THE ORGANIZATION. SUTTER'S LONG TERM PERFORMANCE PLAN APPROACH IS A COMBINATION OF BOTH LONGER TERM MEASURES OF ORGANIZATION SUCCESS AND KEY ORGANIZATION STRATEGIES WHICH REQUIRE THE COMBINED EFFORT OF ALL LEADERSHIP TO ACHIEVE SUCCESS. SUTTER USES A COMMON FATE APPROACH IN THAT ALL LONG TERM PERFORMANCE PLAN PARTICIPANTS ARE MEASURED AGAINST THE SAME, ORGANIZATION-WIDE CRITERIA VS. INDIVIDUAL EFFORTS. THIS FOSTERS A COMMON PURPOSE ACROSS LEADERSHIP AND A SHARED SENSE OF ACCOUNTABILITY FOR THE OVERALL SUCCESS OF SUTTER HEALTH. TO ENSURE THAT EXTRAORDINARY EFFORTS BY INDIVIDUALS CAN BE RECOGNIZED AND THAT ACTIONS OF LEADERSHIP ARE CONSISTENT WITH SUPPORTING SUTTER HEALTH'S OVERALL MISSION, VISION, AND VALUES, SUTTER'S LONG TERM PERFORMANCE PLAN APPROACH ALSO INCORPORATES A COMBINATION OF CEO AND SUTTER HEALTH COMPENSATION COMMITTEE DISCRETION. IN SOME CASES, THE SUTTER HEALTH COMPENSATION COMMITTEE HAS DELEGATED AUTHORITY TO THE PRESIDENT & CEO TO MODIFY INDIVIDUAL AWARDS WITHIN LIMITS THAT HAVE BEEN PRE-APPROVED BY THE SUTTER HEALTH COMPENSATION COMMITTEE. THIS INCLUDES BOTH THE REDUCTION AND INCREASE OF AWARD AMOUNTS. SUCH MODIFICATIONS GENERALLY DO NOT EXCEED +/- 20% AND ARE EMPLOYED JUDICIOUSLY. IN ALL CASES, THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD DETERMINES ACHIEVEMENT OF ORGANIZATION GOALS AND MAKES FINAL AWARD DETERMINATION WHICH MAY RESULT IN A REDUCTION OF AWARD IF APPROPRIATE. ALL SENIOR EXECUTIVE AWARDS ARE REVIEWED FOR COMPENSATION REASONABLENESS AND APPROVED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE PRIOR TO PAYMENT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 7 Non-fixed payments
ExplntnTxt: GW OFFERED AN ANNUAL INCENTIVE COMPENSATION PLAN FOR CERTAIN SENIOR OFFICIALS. THE ANNUAL AWARD OPPORTUNITY IS CAPPED AT A PERCENTAGE OF THEIR SALARY. THE PLAN INCLUDES PROGRAMMATIC GOALS AND OBJECTIVES FOR THE YEAR THAT ARE SPECIFIC TO THEIR DEPARTMENT OR DIVISION, AS WELL AS THE INSTITUTIONAL GOALS. THE INSTITUTIONAL GOALS INCLUDE OPTIMIZATION OF ENROLLMENT AND TUITION REVENUES, GROWTH IN RESEARCH EXPENDITURES, AND GROWTH IN OVERALL FUNDRAISING AND FUNDRAISING SPECIFIC TO STUDENT AID. THE PLAN IS APPROVED ANNUALLY BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES' EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE (THE "COMMITTEE"). PRIOR TO THE PAYOUT, THE COMMITTEE REVIEWS THE PERFORMANCE OF SENIOR OFFICIALS ON THEIR GOALS AND OBJECTIVES AND AWARDS THE INCENTIVE PAYMENTS BASED ON COMPARABLE MARKET DATA. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO ENGAGES ITS INTERNAL AUDITORS TO PERFORM SPECIFIC PROCEDURES TO DETERMINE WHETHER: (1) MANAGEMENT'S REVIEW OF THE COMPENSATION PROCESS FOLLOWED INTERNAL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES; AND (2) CALCULATIONS AND SOURCE DATA USED TO DETERMINE THE INCENTIVE PAYMENTS COMPLY WITH THE PLAN.

THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES HAS THE OVERALL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE COMPENSATION REVIEW OF THE PRESIDENT. AN ANNUAL REVIEW IS BASED ON FOUR FACTORS, SUMMATIVE PERFORMANCE APPRAISAL, ACHIEVEMENT OF ANNUAL GOALS, MARKET ANALYSIS AND INSTITUTIONAL NEEDS. THE PRESIDENT SUBMITS A STATUS REPORT ON THE CURRENT YEAR'S GOALS, YEAR END RESULTS AND PROPOSED GOALS FOR THE UPCOMING YEAR. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE WILL ALSO RECEIVE APPROPRIATE PEER AND BENCHMARK DATA FROM THE HUMAN RESOURCES OFFICE. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES WILL REVIEW THE PRESIDENT'S PERFORMANCE AND DISCUSS THEIR CONCLUSIONS ORALLY WITH THE PRESIDENT TO ENSURE THE ACCURATE AND FAIRNESS OF JUDGEMENTS. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE WILL THEN DISCUSS ITS CONCLUSIONS AND COMPENSATION RECOMMENDATION WITH THE PRESIDENT. THE PRESIDENT HAS A WRITTEN EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT. THE PRESIDENT HAS THE OVERALL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE COMPENSATION REVIEW OF THE VICE PRESIDENTS. A MARKET ANALYSIS IS DONE BY THE HUMAN RESOURCES OFFICE WHICH ALSO INCLUDES PEER AND BENCHAMARK DATA. THIS ANALYSIS IS THEN USED AS A TOOL FOR DETERMINING SALARY CHANGES AND IS REVIEWED WITH THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE PRIOR TO IMPLEMENTATION. THE SCHEDULE J ALSO DETAILS THE TOTAL COMPENSATION PAID TO THE INSTITUTE'S OFFICERS, KEY EMPLOYEES AND HIGHLY COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES. THE ABOVE SCHEDULE J, ALSO INCLUDES AMOUNTS CONTRIBUTED AND DISTRIBUTED FROM THE INSTITUTE'S EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION PLAN. ON JUNE 1ST OF EACH YEAR, THE INSTITUTE DEPOSITS AND INVESTS 10% OF EACH EXECUTIVE OFFICER'S BASE PAY INTO A DEFERRED COMPENSATION ASSET PLAN. THE INITIAL VALUE OF THESE DEPOSITS ARE INCLUDED IN THE "DEFERRED COMPENSATION" COLUMN ON SCHEDULE J. VESTING OCCURS 3 YEARS FOLLOWING THE INITIAL DEPOSIT. EVEN THOUGH THIS SCHEDULE RECOGNIZES DEFERRED COMPENSATION AS WAGES EARNED, THIS TYPE OF COMPENSATION MAY BE FORFEITED, IF THE OFFICER IS NO LONGER EMPLOYED AT THE INSTITUTE. YEARLY, THE VESTED DEPOSITS AND ANY ASSOCIATED REALIZED GAINS OR LOSSES WILL BE DISTRIBUTED TO EACH EXECUTIVE OFFICER. THESE DISTRIBUTIONS ARE INCLUDED IN THE "OTHER COMPENSATION" COLUMN IN SCHEDULE J. EFFECTIVELY, THE VALUE OF THE ORIGINAL DEPOSITS ARE BEING REPORTED AS COMPENSATION TWICE ON THE SCHEDULE J. COLUMN F, ON SCHEDULE J, SHOWS THE AMOUNTS WHICH ARE BEING DUPLICATED FROM THE PRIOR YEAR.

TRAVEL FOR THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE MAY BE AUTHORIZED WHEN THE SPOUSE'S PRESENCE IS EXPECTED OR IS APPROPRIATE FOR THE PURPOSES OF THE TRAVEL. TO OBTAIN AUTHORIZATION FOR THE SPOUSE'S TRAVEL, THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED TO WRITE A BRIEF MEMORANDUM TO THE CHAIR OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES REQUESTING THE TRAVEL. IF APPROVED, THE CHAIR OF THE BOARD SHALL SIGN THE MEMORANDUM. SINCE EXPENSES FOR SPOUSAL TRAVEL WOULD ONLY BE APPROVED IN CIRCUMSTANCES WHERE THERE IS A BUSINESS PURPOSE FOR SUCH TRAVEL, THE PAYMENT OF SUCH EXPENSES WOULD BE TREATED AS A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT.

HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES OR INITIATION FEES: THE PRIOR PRESIDENT WAS PROVIDED MEMBERSHIP TO A LOCAL COUNTRY CLUB TO FACILITATE THE CONDUCT OF COLLEGE BUSINESS AND CONSEQUENTLY IT IS NOT TREATED AS A TAXABLE BENEFIT. THE CURRENT PRESIDENT HAS NOT BEEN PROVIDED WITH THIS BENEFIT. THE TRAVEL IS CONSIDERED NECESSARY FOR THE PRESIDENT'S POSITION AND IS THEREFORE NOT TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION.

LEX MCMILLAN, PRESIDENT THRU MAY 2017, PARTICIPATED IN A 457(F) DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN. THE COLLEGE CONTRIBUTED $33,000 TO THE PLAN DURING THE CALENDAR YEAR. THERE WERE ALSO $70,562 IN DISTRIBUTIONS FROM THE PLAN DURING THE CALENDAR YEAR.

LEX MCMILLIAN, PRESIDENT THRU MAY 2017, PARTICIPATED IN AN ANNUAL VARIABLE COMPENSATION PROGRAM ("ANNUAL VCP"). THE ANNUAL VCP PAYMENT WAS CAPPED AT 15% OF BASE SALARY AND WAS CONTINGENT ON THE ACHIEVEMENT OF ATTAINABLE BUSINESS PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGE'S COMPENSATION COMMITTEE. THE AMOUNT IS DETERMINED BY THE COMMITTEE THROUGH AN ANNUAL REVIEW PROCESS BASED ON THE EMPLOYEE'S PERFORMANCE, INDEPENDENT MARKET DATA, THE COMMITTEE'S COMPENSATION PHILOSOPHY AND OTHER FACTORS WHICH THE COMMITTEE MAY DEEM RELEVANT.

PARTICIPANTS COULD CHOOSE EITHER A LUMP SUM PAYMENT IN THE MONTH FOLLOWING RETIREMENT OR APPROXIMATELY A NINE MONTH CONTINUATION PAYMENT. Travel for companions and gross up payments were provided to an officer of the University. These benefits were provided as taxable compensation. The non-taxable benefit is included in Part II, Column D. A personal residence was provided to the President as a mandatory condition of employment and was not taxable based on section 119 of IRC.

The President participates in a non qualified deferred compensation retirement plan. The plan was created during 2010 with the approval of the Executive Committee, an independent and disinterested party, in order to align the President's total compensation with comparable universities and to ensure the President's long-term employment with Clarkson University. The current year distribution from the plan was $450,000, plus accrued interest, for a total of $471,669. This distribution included $250,000 of prior year contributions, which have been previously reported on Form 990 over the past two years.

The Executive Committee may, at its discretion, award the President a performance award each year in connection with an evaluation of his performance. The evaluation is based upon his accomplishments against goals and objectives during the year. The President may, at his discretion, award employees with a performance award. The Vice President for Development & Alumni Relations and the Head Women's Hockey Coach were both given this award based on an evaluation of their performance. The evaluation is based upon their accomplishments against goals and objectives during the year.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 4b Supplemental nonqualified retirement plan
ExplntnTxt: LIKE MANY OF ITS PEERS, HARVARD UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS A DEFERRED COMPENSATION ACCOUNT ("DCA") FOR THE PRESIDENT TO RECOGNIZE EXCEPTIONAL SERVICE AND ENCOURAGE RETENTION. UNDER THE TERMS OF THE PLAN, HARVARD'S BOARD OF TRUSTEES (KNOWN AS THE HARVARD CORPORATION) DETERMINES ANNUALLY WHETHER AND HOW MUCH TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE DCA. AMOUNTS CONTRIBUTED TO THE DCA VEST ACCORDING TO A THREE-YEAR PLAN CYCLE IN WHICH ALL AMOUNTS CONTRIBUTED IN YEARS 1, 2, AND 3 VEST AFTER YEAR 3. THE THREE-YEAR PLAN CYCLE RUNS FROM CALENDAR YEAR 2015 TO CALENDAR YEAR 2017, AND VESTS IN CALENDAR YEAR 2018. DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2017, THE CORPORATION VOTED TO CREDIT $500,000 TO THE DCA. THE $500,000 IS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (C). DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2015 AND CALENDAR YEAR 2016, THE CORPORATION VOTED TO CREDIT $300,000 AND $400,000 TO THE DCA, WHICH WAS REPORTED AS DEFERRED COMPENSATION IN THE UNIVERSITY'S FY16 AND FY17 FORM 990, RESPECTIVELY. THE AMOUNT OF BONUS ACTUALLY PAID AT THE END OF THE FISCAL YEAR IS BASED ON THE BOARD'S EVALUATION OF THE PRESIDENT'S PERFORMANCE. THE SEMINARY'S PRESIDENT, CFO, AND THE VP FOR LEGAL AFFAIRS ARE ALSO OFFICERS OF YESHIVA UNIVERSITY, AN AFFILIATED BUT UNRELATED ORGANIZATION FOR FORM 990 REPORTING PURPOSES. THESE OFFICERS ARE PAID SOLELY BY YESHIVA UNIVERSITY THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY'S PAYROLL SYSTEM AND THEIR FULL COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS ARE REPORTED ON YESHIVA UNIVERSITY'S FORM 990.

The college provides a residence for personal use to the president and five of the other officers. The housing is excluded from taxable income under IRS code section 119 and included in column D in schedule J, Part II.

The College provided a taxable housing allowance and automobile allowance benefits to Dr. James S. Dlugos, President, in the amount of $15,000 and $9,600, respectively. The College paid country club dues for the VP/Chief Advancement Officer as nontaxable benefits. The membership is for business purposes and all personal benefits received from the membership is reimbursed to the College.

Payments for the business use of personal residence. The University makes an annual payment of $15,000 to the President for the use of her home for university functions. This arrangement is authorized by the Board of Trustees and is included as part of the President's employment contract. It is also included in the President's taxable income.

The Board of Trustees established a Deferred Compensation Plan, and a Non-Qualified 457(F) Plan for the President of the University. The amount accrued in calendar year 2017 for the Deferred Compensation Plan was $300,000; the amount accrued in calendar year 2017 for the Non-Qualified 457(F) Plan was $36,662. These amounts are included as Deferred Income on both Part VII and on Schedule J. The President may exercise these upon separation from the University.

The College requires the President and VP for Student Affairs to reside on campus as a condition of their employment; therefore the College owned housing is provided for them. In addition, the College pays for reasonable costs of housekeeping to maintain the president's residence. Because these benefits are nontaxable, they are not included in the employee's Form W-2. However, they are included in Part II, Column D. Business travel is allowed for the president and CIO when traveling across the continent or overseas. Business air travel is allowed for other members of senior staff when the travel is ten hours or more. Other services provided to the president include payment for membership in one club in Manhattan, such as the Yale Club, for the purpose of meeting with College constituents, sponsoring College events and otherwise conducting College business.

DETAIL OF ADDITIONAL BENEFITS PROVIDED FIRST CLASS OR CHARTER TRAVEL IN LIMITED CIRCUMSTANCES, THE PRESIDENT AND PROVOST OR OTHER KEY EMPLOYEE OF THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER (THE "UNIVERSITY") MAY TRAVEL FIRST CLASS IF CERTAIN TIME/DISTANCE REQUIREMENTS ARE MET AND A VALID UNIVERSITY-RELATED BUSINESS PURPOSE FOR THE TRAVEL EXISTS. TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS IN LIMITED CIRCUMSTANCES, THE SPOUSE OF THE PRESIDENT AND PROVOST OR OTHER KEY EMPLOYEE MAY TRAVEL FOR LEGITIMATE UNIVERSITY-RELATED BUSINESS PURPOSES. EXAMPLES OF SUCH TRAVEL INCLUDE ATTENDANCE AT FUNDRAISING OR ALUMNI EVENTS. IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE LEGAL STANDARDS, AND ON THESE LIMITED OCCASIONS, THE UNIVERSITY WILL REIMBURSE THE TRAVEL EXPENSES FOR SPOUSAL TRAVEL AS A BUSINESS EXPENSE ONLY IF THE SPOUSAL TRAVEL SERVES A "BONA FIDE BUSINESS PURPOSE" OF THE UNIVERSITY. TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS THE UNIVERSITY MAY PROVIDE TAX GROSS-UP PAYMENTS UNDER CERTAIN CIRCUMSTANCES AS APPROVED BY THE BOARD. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT GENERALLY PROVIDE TAX INDEMNIFICATIONS. ONE OFFICER RECEIVED A GROSS-UP PAYMENT THAT WAS TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE/PERSONAL SERVICES AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT, THE PRESIDENT AND PROVOST ARE REQUIRED TO LIVE IN A HOME ON THE UNIVERSITY'S CAMPUS WHICH IS FURNISHED AND MAINTAINED AT THE UNIVERSITY'S EXPENSE. SOCIAL CLUB DUES THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES A SOCIAL CLUB MEMBERSHIP, TO BE USED BY CERTAIN OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES IN CONNECTION WITH THEIR DUTIES. THESE OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY PERSONAL USE OF THE CLUB MEMBERSHIP. SEVEN OFFICERS, FOUR KEY EMPLOYEES AND ONE FORMER OFFICER RECEIVED SOCIAL CLUB DUES THAT WERE TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION. --------------------

On-campus housing is provided to the President as a condition of employment and is non-taxable under IRC-119.

The College has a Total Compensation Philosophy which has been approved by the Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees and has been communicated to all staff. Compensation for the President and Officers is targeted at the median of the defined peer group. The peer group of colleges includes the Associated Colleges of the Midwest (ACM) and the Great Lakes Colleges Association (GLCA). The Compensation Committee periodically reviews IRS Form 990 filings from both groups as well as the ACM and GLCA and CUPA surveys to ensure that total compensation levels for the President and Officers conforms to the approved total compensation policy.

The Board of Trustees established a 457(f) Plan for the President of the College for the period June 1, 2014 through year 2017. Cumulative amount credited to the 457(f) Plan to date was $438,638. Full vesting occurred on May 31, 2018, at which time the President was eligible to receive the full distribution. Interest is credited using the prime rate.

SUE KING WILLCOX $ 12,526 COMPENSATION IS REPORTED ON THE FORM 990 IN THE YEAR THE COMPENSATION IS EARNED BY OR AWARDED TO AN INDIVIDUAL, EVEN IF THE COMPENSATION IS NOT PAID TO THE INDIVIDUAL, IS NOT FULLY VESTED, OR IS SUBJECT TO SUBSTANTIAL RISK OF FORFEITURE. IF COMPENSATION IS EARNED OR AWARDED IN ONE YEAR BUT PAID IN A LATER YEAR, THEN THE COMPENSATION IS GENERALLY REPORTED A SECOND TIME ON THE FORM 990 IN THE YEAR THE COMPENSATION IS PAID TO THE INDIVIDUAL. AS A RESULT OF THE REPORTING REQUIREMENT, AN ORGANIZATION COULD BE REQUIRED TO REPORT THE SAME COMPENSATION ON FORM 990 IN TWO DIFFERENT YEARS.

Form 990, Schedule J, Part I Line 1 - The President of the College is provided a home in close proximity to the campus as a condition of his employment. The value of the residence provided to the President on campus has not been assigned a fair market value and is not included in Schedule J, Part II, Column (d). As required, the College provides cleaning and maintenance services for the employer provided housing. The college occasionally requires the travel, at various business functions, of the President's spouse (who is also a part-time employee of the College, but whose compensation did not exceed $10,000 and therefore is not required to be disclosed on Schedule L) and the VP for Advancement's spouse. Travel depends on the nature of the function and the duties of the spouses are determined in advance and approved. In such instances full substantiation of the expenses is also required. Finally, the College pays the social club membership dues of the President and the Vice President for Advancement so that they may host donors and other business guests of the College at activities designed to benefit the College. To the extent that these individuals incur any personal expenses related to their social club usage, they are required to reimburse the College. All business expenditures must be substantiated to be excluded from their wages.

FIRST-CLASS OR CHARTER TRAVEL The president is the only position reported in the Form 990 for which the university paid or reimbursed business or first-class travel. The university did not utilize chartered flights for air travel. Extensive travel is required of the position of president and they are encouraged by the Board of Trustees to travel business or first class on flights of two hours or more. This provision is made for several reasons 1) business or first-class travel allows for the most flexibility to accommodate a travel schedule that must frequently be altered, often at the last minute to accommodate donors' schedules, add critical meetings, or to take advantage of other strategic opportunities for the university, 2) circumstances sometimes call for the president to return to campus without notice, or to remain on campus when a trip was planned, and first or business-class travel best accommodates these changing conditions, and 3) the Board of Trustees wishes the president to be at their best performance representing and seeking funding for the university during often grueling travel itineraries for meetings frequently critical to the institution's well-being. This accommodation was not treated as taxable compensation. H0USING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE: The president is required to live on campus in the university-owned president's residence where they regularly hold university events. Because the president accepts this requirement as a condition of employment, the residence is on university premises, and it is provided for the convenience of the university, under IRS rules it is not considered a taxable benefit to the president. As required by IRS Form 990, the value ofthe portion of the residence used by the president for personal living quarters has been estimated and is included in the amounts reported on Form 990, Schedule J, Part II, Column (D). HEALTH CLUB MEMBERSHIP: The president's health club membership is paid by the university and reported as taxable compensation.

PARTICIPATION IN A NON-QUALIFIED PLAN: A PARTICIPANT'S ENTITLEMENT TO BENEFITS WILL VEST ON THE PARTICIPANT'S VESTING DATE PROVIDED THE PARTICIPANT HAS REMAINED IN CONTINUOUS EMPLOYMENT IN THE SAME POSITION WHILE PARTICIPATING IN THIS PLAN. A PARTICIPANT WILL HAVE ONLY ONE VESTING DATE FOR ALL ELECTIVE DEFERRALS AND OTHER PLAN CONTRIBUTIONS MADE ON THE PARTICIPANT'S BEHALF DURING ALL PLAN YEARS. A PARTICIPANT'S ENTITLEMENT TO BENEFITS WILL ALSO VEST (A) IF THE PARTICIPANT DIES WHILE STILL EMPLOYED BY THE EMPLOYER; (B) IF THE PARTICIPANT'S EMPLOYMENT TERMINATES DUE TO TOTAL DISABILITY; OR (C) IF THE EMPLOYER TERMINATES THE PARTICIPANT'S EMPLOYMENT FOR ANY REASON OTHER THAN FOR CAUSE. ANY PORTION OF THE PARTICIPANT'S ENTITLEMENT TO BENEFITS THAT IS NOT VESTED WHEN THE PARTICIPANT'S EMPLOYMENT WITH THE EMPLOYER TERMINATES, INCLUDING ELECTIVE DEFERRALS, WILL BE FORFEITED. THE EMPLOYER WILL DISTRIBUTE A PARTICIPANT'S BENEFITS UNDER THE PLAN AS SOON AS PRACTICABLE AFTER THE PARTICIPANT'S ENTITLEMENT BECOMES VESTED. FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN F
ExplntnTxt: COMPENSATION REPORTED IN PRIOR FORM 990: COMPENSATION IS REPORTED ON THE FORM 990 IN THE YEAR THAT THE COMPENSATION IS EARNED BY OR AWARDED TO AN INDIVIDUAL, EVEN IF THE COMPENSATION IS NOT PAID TO THE INDIVIDUAL, IS NOT FULLY VESTED, OR IS SUBJECT TO SUBSTANTIAL RISK OF FORFEITURE. IF COMPENSATION IS EARNED OR AWARDED IN ONE YEAR BUT PAID IN A LATER YEAR, THEN THE COMPENSATION IS REPORTED A SECOND TIME ON THE FORM 990 IN THE YEAR THE COMPENSATION IS VESTED OR PAID TO THE INDIVIDUAL.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a First-class or charter travel
ExplntnTxt: Dartmouth travel policy allows for first or business class air travel for business purposes in limited circumstances. Consistent with this policy, on infrequent occasions senior officers flew first class with the President's approval. The lack of a major commercial airport within 80 miles of Dartmouth requires use of charter air travel to fulfill the business travel requirements of the President. For this reason, the President and certain senior officers had access for business purposes to charter flight service, the cost of which was fully defrayed by private donations designated for this purpose.

ExplntnTxt: Eligible executives participate in a program that provides for supplemental retirement benefits. The payment of benefits under the program, if any, is entirely dependent upon the facts and circumstances under which the executive terminates employment with the organization. METHOD USED TO ESTABLISH PRESIDENTS COMPENSATION ALL EXECUTIVE OFFICER COMPENSATION, INCLUDING THE PRESIDENTS COMPENSATION, IS REVIEWED ANNUALLY BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES BASED ON COMPARABLE COMPENSATION FROM SIMILAR INSTITUTIONS, AND REASONABLENESS OF EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION IS ASSESSED BY AN INDEPENDENT EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION CONSULTANT. BASED ON THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS, THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE APPROVES EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION. APPROVAL IS DOCUMENTED IN THE MINUTES OF THE COMPENSATION AND EXECUTIVE COMMITTEES.

Linfield College provides housing for the President. He is required to live there as a condition of his employment and for the convenience of the employer. The college pays club dues to Michelbook Country Club, the University Club and the Arlington Club as part of the President's role (e.g. fundraising, external relations, meeting space, etc.) The college occasionally pays travel costs for the president's spouse if she is attending alumni gatherings or other events where it benefits the college to have the president and his wife present.
Thomas Hellie participates in a 457(f). Contributions to the plan are reported as deferred compensation as they are accrued. In 2016, contributions of $79,512 were deferred under the plan.

A residence and limited personal services are provided for the convenience of the President of the College. A housing allowance of $12,000 is included in the President's non-taxable compensation. In addition, the College provides a de minimis gross-up payment to senior staff to cover the tax impact of long-term disability insurance.

EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2003, THE UNIVERSITY ADOPTED THE SUPPLEMENTAL RETENTION AND RETIREMENT PLAN (SERRP), AN UNFUNDED DEFINED BENEFIT RETIREMENT PLAN FOR SENIOR EXECUTIVES. THE PURPOSE OF THE PLAN IS TO REWARD PERFORMANCE, LOYALTY AND CONTINUOUS SERVICE OF THOSE INDIVIDUALS SELECTED AS PARTICIPANTS IN THE PLAN. UNDER THE TERMS OF THE PLAN, THE UNIVERSITY WILL PAY PARTICIPANTS THE LUMP SUM EQUIVALENT VALUE OF A LIFE ANNUITY PAYING 60% OF THE AVERAGE OF THE PARTICIPANT'S THREE FINAL CALENDAR YEARS OF BASE SALARY AND ANNUAL INCENTIVE COMPENSATION. THE BENEFIT IS OFFSET FOR EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS (AND RELATED EARNINGS) TO THE 403(B) SAVINGS PLAN AS WELL AS THE EMPLOYER-PROVIDED PORTION OF SOCIAL SECURITY. SERRP BENEFITS VEST UPON A PARTICIPANT ATTAINING AGE 65 WITH 25 YEARS OF SERVICE. ANY PARTICIPANT WHO LEAVES THE SERVICE OF THE UNIVERSITY BEFORE REACHING BOTH OF THESE MILESTONES IS NOT ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE A BENEFIT FROM THE PLAN. EFFECTIVE DECEMBER 31, 2014, THE ACTUARIAL EQUIVALENT LUMP SUM BENEFIT PAYABLE AT AGE 65 WAS SET AT A FIXED AMOUNT. WHILE THE CHANGE IN THE PRESENT VALUE INCLUDES CHANGES IN THE DISCOUNT RATE USED FOR ACCOUNTING PURPOSES, THE ACTUAL LUMP SUM IS BASED ON A FIXED INTEREST RATE OF 6%. THE AMOUNTS REPORTED IN THIS FORM 990 REPRESENT THE INCREASE IN THE PRESENT VALUE OF THE ACCRUED BENEFIT (WITHOUT REGARD TO VESTING). THE NET INCREASE IN THE PRESENT VALUE OF THE ACCRUED BENEFIT BY PARTICIPANTS INCLUDED ON SCHEDULE J IS: HEATHER A. O'CONNELL,$28,577; CAROLE D. PITCHER, $47,856; PETER BAILEY $46,660; ERIN DIMARCO, $2,622 AND JAMES WILSON, JR. $23,960.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES BONUSES TO THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED ON SCHEDULE J. IT UTILIZES A NUMBER OF PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES TO DETERMINE THE BONUS AMOUNTS. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES MEETS TO SPECIFICALLY DISCUSS EXECUTIVE BONUS AMOUNTS. THE COMMITTEE UTILIZES AN INDEPENDENT COMPENSATION CONSULTANT THAT PROVIDES INFORMATION FROM A VARIETY OF COMPENSATION STUDIES AND SURVEYS INCLUDING 990'S. THE COMMITTEE FOLLOWED THE PROCESS TO ESTABLISH THE PRESUMPTION THAT COMPENSATION PAID TO THE ORGANIZATION'S PRESIDENT AND OTHER TOP MANAGEMENT FOR PURPOSES OF SECTION 4958 BY RELYING ON PROFESSIONAL ADVICE IN THE WRITTEN OPINION OF REASONABLENESS FROM THE INDEPENDENT COMPENSATION CONSULTANT. ONCE ALL OF THIS INFORMATION IS GATHERED AND REVIEWED, THE COMMITTEE APPROVES THE BONUS FOR EACH EXECUTIVE. ALL COMPENSATION, INCLUDING COMPENSATION COMMITTEE APPROVED BONUSES, ARE REPORTED TO THE FULL BOARD OF TRUSTEES.

PART I, LINE 1B ALTHOUGH A WRITTEN POLICY DOES NOT EXIST, THE COLLEGE'S BOARD APPROVES THE HOUSING ALLOWANCE AND SOCIAL CLUB PAYMENTS. SOCIAL CLUB PAYMENTS ARE SUPPORTED BY INVOICES AND ARE PROCESSED THROUGH THE COLLEGE'S ACCOUNTS PAYABLE PROCESS. THE HOUSING ALLOWANCE IS ALSO SUPPORTED BY WRITTEN DOCUMENTATION.

THE PROPERTY IS USED FOR MANY COLLEGE FUNCTIONS, MEALS, AND RECEPTIONS INVOLVING FACULTY, STAFF, STUDENTS, DONORS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. THERE IS NO PRIVATE RESIDENCE FOR THE FAMILY. AS PART OF A CONTRACTUAL AGREEMENT, THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED TO LIVE ON THE PROPERTY AND HOST EVENTS LISED ABOVE. SOCIAL CLUB DUES ARE PAID BY THE COLLEGE AND ARE USED FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES ONLY. MEETS MONTHLY WITH THE DES MOINES AREA PARTNERSHIP ORGANIZATION AND DONORS IN THE AREA. THE COLLEGE REQUIRES AND FURNISHES A HOME FOR THE PRESIDENT'S USE AS A CONDITION OF HIS EMPLOYMENT. THE PRESIDENT IS TO USE THE HOME TO ENTERTAIN OR HOLD MEETINGS FOR BOARD MEMBERS, VARIOUS COLLEGE EMPLOYEES, POTENTIAL DONORS, AND STUDENTS. THIS IS A SCHOOL POLICY AND IS PART OF HIS EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT. THE PRESIDENT HAS USED THE RESIDENCE EXTENSIVELY FOR COLLEGE BUSINESS. HE HAS AN OFFICE IN THE HOUSE SOLELY DESIGNATED FOR COLLEGE WORK THAT HE USES EACH DAY AND ON WEEKENDS. THE PRESIDENT ENTERTAINS THE TRUSTEES WHICH DROP BY CONTINUOUSLY THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. THE PRESIDENT WILL HOLD CABINET MEETINGS AT THE HOUSE PERIODICALLY. MEETINGS WITH COMMUNITY OFFICIALS OCCUR FREQUENTLY AT THE HOUSE. THE PRESIDENT MEETS POTENTIAL AND LONG-TIME DONORS AT HIS HOME SEVERAL TIMES A MONTH TO SECURE CONTRIBUTIONS FOR THE COLLEGE. HE HOLDS A FRESHMAN SEMINAR CLASS AT THE HOME SEVERAL TIMES A MONTH. THE PRESIDENT HAS ALSO ALLOWED STUDENTS TO STAY AT THE HOUSE FOR SHORT STAYS WHEN NEEDED. HIS HOME IS ALWAYS OPEN TO STUDENTS TO DROP BY AND VISIT. THE PRESIDENT PERFORMS A MEANINGFUL PORTION OF HIS DUTIES AT HIS HOME.

Hiram College provides housing for the President for entertaining, meetings and conducting business on behalf of the college. The President is also provided a social membership to a club of her choice.
The President is required to live in housing provided on campus. The value of this housing is excluded from taxable income.

The compensation of the President is reviewed annually by the Board of Trustees. The result of the deliberations and decisions are documented in a statement of salary letter sent to the President and the Director of Human Resources.

UNIVERSITY POLICY REQUIRES ADDITIONAL DOCUMENTATION IN THE CASE OF FIRST OR BUSINESS CLASS AIRFARE TO DOCUMENT THE REASON OF THE ADDITIONAL EXPENSE. The President receives a housing allowance as he conducts significant University business in his private home.

The Personnel Committee of Quinnipiac University facilitates the evaluation process and salary review of the President and Vice Presidents of the University. The Committee meets on a regular basis at least two times each year to evaluate the performance of the President and Vice Presidents based on the success or failure of meeting their approved annual goals and objectives. Their salary adjustments based on merit are tied to this evaluation, comparative salary data from similar institutions and recommendations of the President or, in the case of the President, the Committee. The Committee has authority as delegated to it by the full Board of Trustees to execute and amend the contracts for the President and Vice Presidents of the University.
Severance payment was made to Thomas Moore, former Men's Head Basketball Coach.

Housing Allowance - A residence on the employer's premises is used for both University business functions and as a personal residence by the President for the convenience of the employer and is treated as nontaxable compensation. The value of the personal space within the residence is included as a nontaxable benefit on Schedule J. Health or social club dues - The University paid social club membership dues for the President. Since the use of the memberships were for business purposes it was not treated as taxable compensation. Personal Services - The University regularly cleans the President's residence and the value of the maintenance of the personal space is taxed accordingly.
The President of Roger Williams University participated in a University 457(f) plan and $25,000 was accrued under the plan in calendar year 2017.

For University non-aligned employees, merit based compensation may be granted as either a base salary increase or a one-time bonus. Qualifications for receiving a bonus include performance exceeding expectations or taking on additional duties due to staff vacancies or temporary absences. For the compensation of the University's President, the bonus amount (if any) is determined by an employment agreement along with a review and approval of the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees, who are all independent of the President. In the case of all other officers and other key employees, the bonus amount (if any) is determined via the same process as other compensation for officers and other key employees, including review by the University's President, who is independent of the other officers or key employees.

THE PRESIDENT OF ROBERTS IS CONSIDERED A KEY REPRESENTATIVE OF THE COLLEGE AND THEREFORE TRAVEL COSTS RELATED TO CERTAIN OFFICIAL COLLEGE MEETINGS ARE NONTAXABLE TO THE PRESIDENT. THE COLLEGE PRESIDENT RESIDES IN COLLEGE PROVIDED HOUSING WHICH ALSO SERVES AS A PLACE FOR MEETINGS WITH COLLEGE GUESTS, STUDENTS, DONORS, AND ALUMNI AT VARIOUS TIMES THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. THE COLLEGE PAYS DUES FOR THE PRESIDENTS CLUB MEMBERSHIP IN ROCHESTER TO PROVIDE QUALITY, OFF-CAMPUS MEETING VENUES. ONLY INDIVIDUALS ARE ALLOWED TO JOIN THIS CLUB THAT THE PRESIDENT ONLY USES FOR COLLEGE RELATED PURPOSES.

HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE ARE GRANTED TO EMPLOYEES THAT ARE REQUIRED TO LIVE ON CAMPUS, ARE PART-TIME COACHES, OR IF INCLUDED IN THE TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT. INFORMATION REGARDING THE HOUSING ALLOWANCE/RESIDENCE IS CONTAINED IN THE EMPLOYEES' OFFER LETTERS AND SUCH EMPLOYEES SIGN A CONTRACT EACH JULY FOR THE UPCOMING LEASE TERM.

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES DR. JOSEPH NYRE, PRESIDENT, HOUSING ON THE COLLEGE'S CAMPUS FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER (IONA COLLEGE) AND AS A CONDITION OF HIS EMPLOYMENT. THE $78,000 FAIR MARKET VALUE OF SUCH LODGING IS EXCLUDED FROM THE PRESIDENT'S TAXABLE INCOME AND IS NOT REPORTED ON FORM 990, SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (D) AS A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT. ADDITIONAL PAYMENT FOR HOUSEHOLD SERVICES (I.E., IMPUTED INCOME AND GROSS-UP) IS REPORTED ON BOTH THE PRESIDENT'S FORM W-2 AND ON FORM 990, SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B)(III). ADDITIONALLY, A CONTRACTUAL TUITION CREDIT PAYMENT AND A COMPLETION BONUS ARE INCLUDED FOR 2017. THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS AN INSTITUTIONAL MEMBERSHIP AT THE "HOME" GOLF CLUB OF THE IONA COLLEGE GOLF TEAM. THE PRESIDENT USES THE SOCIAL CLUB PRIMARILY FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES. ANY INCREMENTAL CHARGES FOR PERSONAL USE ARE PAID PERSONALLY BY THE PRESIDENT.
The college provided Timothy Cluess, Mens Basketball Coach, with a contractual stay bonus which is reported on Schedule J, Part II, Column (B)(II).

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES A RESIDENCE AND HOUSEHOLD SERVICES FOR THE PRESIDENT, JAMES REYNOLDS. THE RESIDENCE IS NOT INCLUDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S TAXABLE INCOME. THE RESIDENCE IS FURNISHED FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE COLLEGE, AND IT IS AVAILABLE FOR USE TO HOST FACULTY, STAFF, AND STUDENT FUNCTIONS. THE PRESIDENT WAS REQUIRED TO LIVE IN THE RESIDENCE AS A CONDITION OF HER EMPLOYMENT, AND HER RESIDENCE IS CONTIGUOUS TO THE COLLEGE'S CAMPUS.

LLU'S SENIOR EXECUTIVES ARE EMPLOYED BY LLUH AND LLUH BENEFITS PROVIDE FOR PAYMENT OF THE TRAVEL EXPENSES FOR A SPOUSE TO ACCOMPANY AN EMPLOYEE ON ONE BUSINESS TRIP PER YEAR. IF USED, THE TAXABLE COST OF THIS BENEFIT IS INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYEE'S W-2. LLUH BENEFITS PROVIDE FOR GROSS-UP PAYMENTS TO APPROXIMATELY COVER THE TAXES ON THE IMPUTED COST OF GROUP-TERM LIFE INSURANCE COVERAGE IN EXCESS OF $50,000. ALL EMPLOYEES RECEIVED THIS BENEFIT. THE TAXABLE COST OF THIS BENEFIT IS INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYEE'S W-2. LLUH BENEFITS PROVIDE FOR HOUSING ALLOWANCE. IF USED, THE TAXABLE COST OF THIS BENEFIT IS INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYEE'S W-2.
THE ORGANIZATION RELIED ON A RELATED ORGANIZATION THAT USED ONE OR MORE OF THE METHOD DESCRIBED TO ESTABLISH TOP MANAGEMENT OFFICIAL'S COMPENSATION.

THE ORGANIZATION USES COMPARABILITY DATA FROM FORMS 990 OF OTHER SIMILAR ORGANIZATIONS AND FROM A COMPENSATION STUDY TO DETERMINE THE SALARIES FOR THE PRESIDENT/CEO AND OTHER OFFICERS. THE PRESIDENT/CEO'S SALARY IS DETERMINED AND APPROVED BY THE INDEPENDENT BOARD OF DIRECTORS ANNUALLY AFTER REVIEWING COMPARABILITY DATA.

TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS - THE SPOUSES OF THE PRESIDENT, VICE PRESIDENT FOR COLLEGE ADVANCEMENT, AND FORMER VICE PRESIDENT FOR COLLEGE ADVANCEMENT OCCASIONALLY TRAVEL WITH THEM TO PARTICIPATE IN FUNDRAISING EVENTS. THIS TRAVEL IS FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE COLLEGE AND IS STRICTLY FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES. THEREFORE, IT IS NOT TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION. TRAVEL EXPENSES OF THE VICE PRESIDENT ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY THE PRESIDENT. THE TRAVEL EXPENSES OF THE PRESIDENT ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY THE BOARD. TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS - ONE KEY EMPLOYEE AND ONE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE RECEIVED TAX INDEMNIFICATION PAYMENTS INCLUDED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B)(III). HOUSING ALLOWANCE - ON CAMPUS HOUSING IS PROVIDED FOR THE PRESIDENT OF THE COLLEGE AND THE DEAN OF CAMPUS LIFE AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER. THE VALUE OF THE HOUSING IS INCLUDED IN PART II, COLUMN (D). THE VP FOR COLLEGE ADVANCEMENT, FORMER VP FOR COLLEGE ADVANCEMENT, VP FOR ENROLLMENT AND VP FOR COMMUNICATIONS & MARKETING RECEIVE A HOUSING ALLOWANCE WHICH IS TREATED AS TAXABLE AND INCLUDED IN PART II, COLUMN (B)(III). SOCIAL CLUB DUES OR INITIATION FEES - A MEMBERSHIP IN A SOCIAL CLUB IS PROVIDED FOR THE PRESIDENT, AND IS USED FOR FUNDRAISING ACTIVITIES. THE PRESIDENT IDENTIFIES AND PAYS FOR ANY PERSONAL USE OF THE SOCIAL CLUB. PERSONAL SERVICES - IN CONNECTION WITH THE HOUSING PROVIDED FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER, CERTAIN HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES WERE PROVIDED TO THE PRESIDENT. THE VALUE OF THESE SERVICES ARE TREATED AS TAXABLE AND INCLUDED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B)(III). SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 1B: IN CONNECTION WITH THE BENEFITS DISCLOSED ON SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 1, THE ORGANIZATION PROVIDES PURSUANT TO ITS POLICIES AND/OR THE TERMS OF THE EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT OF THE INDIVIDUAL RECEIVING THE BENEFIT.

EFFECTIVE UPON HIS RETIREMENT ON JUNE 30, 2017, TRINITY COLLEGE AND FORMER VP FOR ADVANCEMENT FRACASSO AGREED THAT HE WOULD RECEIVE CERTAIN PAYMENTS UNDER A SEPARATION AGREEMENT. IN 2017, HE RECEIVED TOTAL PAYMENTS OF $157,780 ASSOCIATED WITH THIS AGREEMENT. THESE PAYMENTS ARE INCLUDED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B) (III).

PURSUANT TO THE TERMS OF A SECTION 457(F) DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN, THE PRESIDENT IS ENTITLED TO CERTAIN DEFERRED COMPENSATION BENEFITS WHICH VEST THE EARLIEST OF (1) AGREED UPON DATE; (2) DEATH; (3) DISABILITY; OR (4) INVOLUNTARY TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT FROM THE COLLEGE. A CREDIT OF $27,375 WAS MADE IN 2017 AND IS INCLUDED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (C). IN 2017, AMOUNTS UNDER THE PLAN BECAME VESTED AND WERE PAID TO THE PRESIDENT. THE AMOUNTS PAID ARE REFLECTED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B) (III). PURSUANT TO THE TERMS OF A SECTION 457(F) DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN, THE VP FINANCE IS ENTITLED TO CERTAIN DEFERRED COMPENSATION BENEFITS WHICH VEST THE EARLIEST OF (1) AGREED UPON DATE; (2) DEATH; (3) DISABILITY; OR (4) INVOLUNTRAY TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT FROM THE COLLEGE. A CREDIT OF $5,625 WAS MADE IN 2017 AND IS INCLUDED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (C). PURSUANT TO THE TERMS OF A SECTION 457(F) DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN, THE VP ACADEMIC AFFAIRS IS ENTITLED TO CERTAIN DEFERRED COMPENSATION BENEFITS WHICH VEST THE EARLIEST OF (1) AGREED UPON DATE; (2) DEATH; (3) DISABILITY; OR (4) INVOLUNTARY TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT FROM THE COLLEGE. A CREDIT OF $4,875 WAS MADE IN 2017 AND IS INCLUDED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (C).
A housing allowance of $1,000 per month was paid to the college President. The total amount of the allowance was treated as taxable and included on the President's 2017 Form W-2.

HEALTH AND SOCIAL CLUB DUES AND INITIATION FEES: SOCIAL CLUB DUES AND QUARTERLY REQUIRED MEAL FEES FOR THE PRESIDENT ARE PAID BY MIDWAY UNIVERSITY. THE PERSONAL PORTION OF THE DUES IS ADDED TO THE W-2 OF THE PRESIDENT. MIDWAY UNIVERSITY PROVIDES FOR MEALS TO THE PRESIDENT FOR ON-CAMPUS, BUSINESS ACTIVITIES DIRECTED BY THE BOARD. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE: MIDWAY UNIVERSITY PROVIDES THE PINKERTON-ROUSE HOUSE, A HISTORICAL RESIDENCE, TO THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT, WHICH IS FURNISHED FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY AND IS REQUIRED AS A CONDITION OF THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT. THE TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS ARE MADE TO COVER THE TAXABLE PORTIONS OF THE SOCIAL CLUB DUES AND VEHICLE USE.

PART I QUESTION I: TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016, THE UNIVERSITY REIMBURSED PRESIDENT LIEBOWITZ FOR TRAVEL EXPENSES INCURRED BY HIS SPOUSE WHILE CONDUCTING BUSINESS OF THE UNIVERSITY. SUCH REIMBURSEMENTS WERE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICY. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE: THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED PRESIDENT LIEBOWITZ WITH A HOUSING ALLOWANCE AS A CONDITION OF HIS EMPLOYMENT. THE VALUE OF SUCH HOUSING IS INCLUDABLE AS TAXABLE INCOME UNDER IRS CODE SECTION 119 (D). PERSONAL SERVICES: DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016, THE UNIVERSITY REIMBURSED PRESIDENT LIEBOWITZ FOR PERSONAL LEGAL AND FINANCIAL SERVICE EXPENSES. THE AMOUNT PAID BY THE UNIVERSITY WAS INCLUDED IN THE INDIVIDUAL'S FORM W-2 AND REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN B(III). OTHER BUSINESS EXPENSES: THE UNIVERSITY REIMBURSES ITS OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES FOR ORDINARY AND NECESSARY BUSINESS EXPENSES INCURRED WHILE CONDUCTING BUSINESS OF THE UNIVERSITY. SUCH REIMBURSEMENT IS MADE UNDER AN ACCOUNTABLE PLAN AND REQUIRES SUBSTANTIATION USING THE ORIGINAL EXPENSE DOCUMENTATIONS AND APPROVAL BY APPROPRIATE PARTIES AS AUTHORIZED UNDER UNIVERSITY POLICY. PART I QUESTION 4A SEVERANCE OR CHANGE OF CONTROL PAYMENT THE UNIVERSITY HAS AN EMPLOYMENT AND SEPARATION POLICY THAT COVERS MEMBERS OF THE SENIOR MANAGEMENT GROUP, WHICH PROVIDES SEVERANCE PROVISION RANGING FROM 4 WEEKS TO 20 WEEKS. SOME SENIOR MANAGEMENT MAY HAVE ADDITIONAL SEVERANCE PROVISION AS PART OF THEIR EMPLOYMENT ARRANGEMENT. DAVID BUNIS, CHIEF LEGAL COUNSEL AND PRESIDENT'S ADVISOR, LEFT HIS POSITION AT THE END OF CALENDAR YEAR 2015. AS PART OF HIS SEPARATION AGREEMENT, MR. BUNIS RECEIVED SEVERANCE OF $348,249, WHICH WAS INCLUDED IN HIS W-2 AND REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J PART II COLUMN B(III). BRUCE MAGID, DEAN OF IBS, LEFT HIS POSITION AT THE BEGINNING OF FISCAL YEAR 2017. AS PART OF HIS SEPARATION AGREEMENT, MR. MAGID RECEIVED SEVERANCE OF $259,982, WHICH WAS INCLUDED IN HIS W-2 AND REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J PART II COLUMN B(III). PART I QUESTION 4B DEFERRED COMPENSATION ARRANGEMENT FORMER PRESIDENT LAWRENCE PARTICIPATED IN A NONQUALIFIED DEFERRED COMPENSATION ARRANGEMENT UNDER IRS CODE SECTION 457(F). THE AMOUNT VESTED DURING 2016 AND IS INCLUDED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN B(III).

PART I, LINE 1A TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS IS PROVIDED ONLY TO THE PRESIDENT, WHO REIMBURSES THE COLLEGE FOR THE FULL EXPENSE. HEALTH CLUB DUES ARE REIMBURSED TO MEMBERS OF THE PRESIDENT'S COUNCIL UNDER AN EXECUTIVE WELLNESS REIMBURSEMENT PROGRAM. THIS INCLUDES THE SENIOR VICE PRESIDENTS AND VICE PRESIDENTS REPORTED IN FORM 990 PART VII. THE AMOUNTS ARE INCLUDED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION IN EACH INDIVIDUAL'S FORM W-2. The President of Roger Williams University and Roger Williams University School of Law is compensated by the University. The President's compensation is contractually set and is reviewed by the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees of Roger Williams University, all members of which are independent of the President. The Executive Committee's review currently includes, but is not limited to the use of comparability data and other outside consultants.
The President of Roger Williams University participated in a University 457(f) plan and $25,000 was accrued under the plan in calendar year 2017.

For School of Law non-aligned employees, merit based compensation may be granted as either a base salary increase or a one-time bonus. Qualifications for receiving a bonus include performance exceeding expectations or taking on additional duties due to staff vacancies or temporary absences. In the case of officers and other key employees, the bonus amount (if any) is determined via the same process as other compensation for officers and other key employees, including review by the University's President, who is independent of the other officers or key employees. In addition, the compensation of officers and key employees falls within the parameters of the School of Law's non-aligned merit compensation program that is approved by the University's Board of Trustees on an annual basis.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a First-class or charter travel
ExplntnTxt: The University's written travel policy permits payment only of necessary and reasonable expenses for travel on University business. The University's policies constitute an accountable plan and are designed to comply with applicable Internal Revenue Service rules. Coach class airfare is required except in certain limited circumstances; these include medical necessity, contractual obligations, and scheduled flight segments over six hours in length, when business class fares may be used with prior approval. In rare cases, when an exception applies and no business class fare is available, a first class fare may be used, again with prior approval and documentation. Charter travel is sometimes employed for athletics teams, including coaches, when such travel is the least costly method of transportation.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Travel for companions
ExplntnTxt: Under the University's travel policy, the University does not pay the travel cost of companions, unless there is a valid University business purpose for the companion's travel. Written approval must be obtained in advance from the president, provost, or appropriate dean / vice president documenting the reason for incurring the expense. When the University uses chartered air or ground transportation, travel for companions may occasionally be included if the University incurs no additional cost.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Tax indemnification and gross-up payments
ExplntnTxt: Under the terms of his contract, the President is provided with grossed up payments for dependent tuition reimbursement. Tuition reimbursement of $21,640 was paid and grossed up to $30,375. The entire amount was taxable. Under the terms of the appointment letter, the Provost was provided with grossed up payments as reimbursement for rent and utilities while also maintaining a house in another state during her transition. Expenses of $21,619 were paid and the payment was grossed up to $29,758. The entire amount was taxable compensation. Additionally the Provost is provided with grossed up payments for dependent tuition reimbursement. Tuition reimbursement of $17,318 was paid and grossed up to $23,838. The entire amount was taxable compensation.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Housing allowance or residence for personal use
ExplntnTxt: The president of the University is required to occupy University-owned housing as a condition of employment. Housekeeping staff is provided for such property. The cost of such services not related to public areas of the house is included in compensation reported. The fair market value of the housing provided, based on the appraised value of the house, is reported in the president's compensation as a non-taxable benefit.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Health or social club dues or initiation fees
ExplntnTxt: Social club dues were paid for the president of the University and included in compensation as appropriate.

ExplntnTxt: See the response to Schedule J, Part I, Line 1A for Housing

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 3 Arrangement used to establish the top management official's compensation
ExplntnTxt: The CORD (Compensation and Organizational Development) Committee of the Board of Trustees of Rice University has a written procedure in place to assure the Board of Trustees that compensation arrangements for the president and other organization officers and managers are reasonable. The procedure is designed to comply with the requirements of Section 4958 of the Internal Revenue Code and Internal Revenue Service regulations. The CORD Committee maintains a roster of disqualified persons, as defined by the IRS, for whose compensation the procedure is used. The roster is reviewed periodically but at least annually. The procedure was last discussed with the full board in March 2011. The procedure requires three elements as follows: 1) The terms of transactions are approved by the organization's governing body, or a committee thereof, whose members have no conflict of interest with respect to the arrangement. The Board of Trustees delegated authority to the CORD Committee to act on behalf of the Board in these matters at its meeting on March 25, 1999. Compensation arrangements are reviewed and approved by the CORD Committee before the effective date. Members of the CORD Committee recuse themselves from any vote in which there is a potential or actual conflict of interest. 2) The governing body or committee obtains and relies upon appropriate, comparable data before making its determination. Rice participates in the annual survey by Willis Towers Watson of select universities' executive compensation, and additional appropriate peer surveys. These reports reflect executive compensation in universities of a stature similar to that of Rice, and with which Rice competes for faculty and staff. The CORD Committee may also seek and rely on other relevant information, including compensation paid by other taxable and tax-exempt organizations for functionally comparable positions, geographic market forces, and actual written offers from similar institutions competing for services. The CORD Committee relies on this data and documents any determinations that reasonable compensation is an amount more than the range of comparable data. 3) The governing body or committee adequately documents the basis for making determinations concurrently with making decisions. Minutes documenting the deliberations of the CORD Committee are prepared contemporaneously for review and approval at its next meeting.

Spousal travel of key employees is reimbursed if considered for fund-raising activities, public relations or development. Rev. Kevin Wm. Wildes, SJ, University President, resides in one of the university residence halls. No fee is charged.

The Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees chaired by the Board Chairperson deliberates to determine the President's compensation. Each member of the compensation-setting body is a disinterested party. Jesuit members of the Executive Committee recuse themselves from the salary deliberations. Salary data obtained from the Association of Colleges and University Personnel Administrators, the Association of Jesuit Colleges and Universities and an executive search firm database is used to determine compensation comparability. The decision of the compensation-setting body including terms of the compensation, the date approved, members of the compensation-setting body present during the discussion of the compensation and voting members, comparability data relied on and the source of the data and an affirmation that all members were free of any conflict of interest is documented and retained by the Secretary of the Board of Trustees.

THIS INCLUDES MEMBERSHIPS DUES FOR CURTIS CREEK COUNTRY CLUB IN RENSSELAER, SANDY PINES GOLF COURSE IN DEMOTTE, AND THE COLUMBIA CLUB IN INDIANAPOLIS, BUT NOT PERSONAL EXPENSES INCURRED AT THESE CLUBS. SINCE THE PAYMENT OF THESE EXPENSES IS ENTIRELY FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES, THE AMOUNTS ARE NOT CONSIDERED TAXABLE INCOME TO THE PRESIDENT.

Several of the College's officers are members of the Sisters of St. Dominic of Blauvelt and receive free housing (e.g. a housing allowance) provided by the College. The fair market rental value of the housing allowance (approximately $13,600 per officer) is excluded from these officers' salaries as it represents a permissible non-taxable fringe benefit under Section 107 of the Internal Revenue Code for members of a religious order.

"AS PART OF ITS HISTORIC MISSION OF NURTURING SPIRITUAL DEVELOPMENT IN COMMUNITY FOR MINISTRY, UNION THEOLOGICAL SEMINARY REQUIRES ITS FACULTY TO RESIDE AT THE SEMINARY IN ORDER TO BE READILY AVAILABLE FOR STUDENTS AND FOR SEMINARY EVENTS. THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES PROVIDES AN ANNUAL BONUS, CALCULATED AS A PERCENTAGE OF SALARY, TO FULL TIME, REGULAR FACULTY. THIS BONUS CAN BE BE DEPOSITED IN THE FACULTY MEMBER'S RETIREMENT ACCOUNT OR RECEIVED AS A CASH PAYMENT.

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES HOUSING TO BOTH THE PRESIDENT AND THE PROVOST FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER SO THAT THEY CAN EACH PERFORM ESSENTIAL COLLEGE BUSINESS AND ACTIVITIES AT THE HOME. THIS BENEFIT IS NONTAXABLE.
MIKE AYERS IS THE ONLY ACTIVE PARTICIPANT IN THE 457F PLAN. IN 2017, THERE WERE $25,000 OF EMPLOYEE CONTRIBUTIONS MADE TO THE PLAN.

The President is required by contract to reside on campus. The President's residence is also used for various University and Board of Trustee functions. The University provides for premises housekeeping and maintenance. University policy allows for very limited travel expenses for companions. All presidential travel and other expenses are reviewed yearly by the Audit Committee of the Board of Trustees.

Employment of the President is initiated by the Board of Trustees. The Evaluation Committee of the Board reviews the President's performance and compensation and reports to the full Board. The committee recommends any adjustments to the President's compensation through a resolution that the full Board discusses and votes on. All Board resolutions are public information and are posted on the University's webpage.
As a minister of the Gospel, President Dr. Wenyika received a minister's housing allowance. This was appropriately treated as a nontaxable benefit included in Other Compensation.

BENEFITS PROVIDED - THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY IS REQUIRED TO LIVE IN RESIDENCE AS PART OF HIS CONTRACT. THE RESIDENCE WAS USED FOR OVER 55 UNIVERSITY FUNCTIONS WITH OVER 2,990 GUESTS IN ATTENDANCE DURING THE FISCAL YEAR. THE VALUE OF THE HOUSE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE $24,000 PER YEAR. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT TREAT THIS BENEFIT AS TAXABLE INCOME TO THE PRESIDENT. SPOUSAL TRAVEL IS PERMITTED ONLY FOR THE PRESIDENT'S WIFE AND ONLY WHEN AN APPROPRIATE BUSINESS PURPOSE FOR THE TRIP HAS BEEN ESTABLISHED. THIS SPOUSAL TRAVEL BENEFIT IS ADMINISTERED IN ACCORDANCE WITH IRS GUIDELINES.

WRITTEN REIMBURSEMENT POLICY - THE BENEFITS LISTED ABOVE WERE ENUMERATED IN THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT. THIS CONTRACT WAS DELIBERATED ON AND REVIEWED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES AND LEGAL COUNSEL.

NONQUALIFIED DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLANS - THE UNIVERSITY SPONSORS A SECTION 457(B) AND SECTION 457(F) PLAN FOR CERTAIN EXECUTIVES. THE UNIVERSITY MADE CONTRIBUTIONS FOR ROCKWELL F. JONES OF $17,500 TO THE SECTION 457(B) PLAN AND $40,000 TO THE SECTION 457(F) PLAN. THE TOTAL CONTRIBUTONS OF $57,500 ARE INCLUDED IN PART II, COLUMN C FOR PRESIDENT JONES. ADDITIONALLY, THE FOLLOWING INDIVIDUALS RECEIVED CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE SECTION 457(B) PLAN FROM THE UNIVERSITY: COLLEEN GARLAND - $35,000; SUSAN DILENO - $10,000; AND LAURI STRIMKOVSKY - $10,000. THE AMOUNTS HAVE BEEN INCLUDED IN PART II, COLUMN C FOR THE RESPECTIVE INDIVIDUALS.

WAGNER COLLEGE PROVIDED HOUSING ON ITS BUSINESS PREMISES FOR THE FOLLOWING EMPLOYEES - RICHARD GUARASCI (PRESIDENT) AND LILY D. MCNAIR (PROVOST AND SENIOR VP); THESE INDIVIDUALS WERE REQUIRED TO ACCEPT HOUSING AS A CONDITION OF THEIR EMPLOYMENT AT THE COLLEGE. THE COLLEGE DEEMED IT NECESSARY FOR THESE TWO INDIVIDUALS TO BE AVAILABLE ALL HOURS OF THE DAY AND NIGHT TO ATTEND ANY URGENT SITUATIONS THAT COULD ARISE AFTER NORMAL BUSINESS HOURS. BOTH INDIVIDUALS ARE CHARGED WITH DUTIES OF SECURITY AND STUDENT WELFARE, SUCH AS CAMPUS HOUSING ISSUES, POWER OUTAGES, INCLEMENT WEATHER ISSUES, AND OTHER EMERGENCY SITUATIONS. THIS BENEFIT WAS NOT TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO ANY EMPLOYEE. THE APPROXIMATE NON-TAXABLE VALUES OF THE HOUSING PROVIDED TO THE EMPLOYEES ARE AS FOLLOWS: RICHARD GUARASCI - $51,644, AND LILY D. MCNAIR - $37,184. WAGNER COLLEGE ALSO PROVIDED SOCIAL CLUB DUES FOR RICHARD GUARASCI, AS WELL AS FOR WALTER HAMELINE (DIRECTOR OF ATHLETICS). THESE MEMBERSHIPS ARE FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES ONLY, SPECIFICALLY DONOR DEVELOPMENT AND COLLEGE-RELATED BUSINESS MEETINGS.

WAGNER COLLEGE'S EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE, WHICH IS COMPRISED OF INDEPENDENT MEMBERS OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES, DETERMINES THE COMPENSATION OF THE COLLEGE'S PRESIDENT, AND REVIEWS AND APPROVES THE COMPENSATION OF ALL SENIOR OFFICERS. BOTH THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE AND THE BOARD MUST REVIEW AND APPROVE COMPENSATION. COMPENSATION IS DETERMINED THROUGH REVIEW OF THE FORM 990 OF OTHER COMPARABLE AND LIKE-SIZE ORGANIZATIONS. THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE ALSO REFERS TO COMPARABLES AND SALARY SURVEYS, mainly cUPA, ON AN ANNUAL BASIS TO DETERMINE THE REASONABLENESS OF PROPOSED COMPENSATION AMOUNTS. ANY COMPENSATION DETERMINATIONS OF THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE ARE RECORDED CONTEMPORANEOUSLY IN THE MINUTES OF THE COMMITTEE. DURING THE TAX YEAR ENDED AUGUST 31, 2018, A NATIONAL SEARCH FOR THE COLLEGES NEW PRESIDENT WAS CONDUCTED. THERE WAS A PRESIDENTIAL SEARCH COMMITTEE THAT WORKED HAND-IN-HAND WITH THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE TO SELECT OUR NEW PRESIDENT. DURING THIS EXTENSIVE PROCESS, THE COMMITTEES REVIEWED COMPENSATION STUDIES AND COMPARATIVES IN REGARDS TO THE PRESIDENTS SALARY.

DURING THE CALENDAR YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2017, ONE PERSON LISTED ON FORM 990, PART VII, SECTION A, LINE 1A (PRESIDENT RICHARD GUARASCI) PARTICIPATED IN A SUPPLEMENTAL NONQUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN. HE CONTRIBUTED $17,500 TO THE PLAN IN CALENDAR YEAR 2017.

TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS TRAVEL FOR COMPANION IS VERY LIMITED AND ALWAYS INCLUDES A CLEAR BUSINESS PURPOSE FOR THE COMPANION AND MUST BE PRE-APPROVED BY THE PRESIDENT. PRESIDENT'S COMPANION IS APPROVED BY THE CHAIR OF BOARD OF TRUSTEES. ALL TRAVEL BENEFITS PROVIDED WERE DETERMINED TO BE FOR A BUSINESS PURPOSE AND THEREFORE NOT INCLUDED IN TAXES AND WAGES.

HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE THE PRESIDENT AND PRESIDENT-EMERITUS OF THE COLLEGE ARE PROVIDED WITH HOUSING IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO THE CAMPUS IN ORDER FOR THEM TO ATTEND TO EMERGENT SITUATIONS ON A 24/7 BASIS. THE HOUSING IS PROVIDED AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT, IS USED FOR COLLEGE BUSINESS AND ENTERTAINMENT PURPOSES AND AS A CONVENIENCE TO THE COLLEGE TO ENABLE THEM TO PERFORM THEIR DUTIES. THE FAIR MARKET VALUE OF RESIDENCES IS SHOWN IN COLUMN D, AMOUNTS ARE BASED ON THE VALUE OF PROPERTY AND FOR THE PRESIDENT EMERITUS APPORTIONED ACCORDING TO PERSONAL USE AND ARE REPORTED IN COLUMNS D and B(iii) ON SCHEDULE J as appropriate.

HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES OR INITIATION FEES THE COLLEGE PAYS CLUB MEMBERSHIP FEES FOR FOUR EXECUTIVES, WHICH ARE INTENDED TO BE USED EXCLUSIVELY FOR THE COLLEGE'S BUSINESS ENTERTAINMENT OR COLLEGE SPONSORED EVENTS. TO THE EXTENT THERE IS ANY PERSONAL USE OF THESE PRIVILEGES, THE INDIVIDUAL EXECUTIVES ARE TAXED ON THE VALUE OF THE USE. ONLY ONE OF THE FOUR EXECUTIVES ARE TAXED ON PERSONAL USE OF THE MEMBERSHIP. THE OTHER THREE EXECUTIVES USE THE MEMBERSHIP EXCLUSIVELY FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES.

SUPPLEMENTAL NON-QUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2011,THE COLLEGE PUT IN PLACE A NON-QUALIFIED SUPPLEMENTAL EXECUTIVE RETIREMENT PLAN ("SERP") FOR THE PRESIDENT OF THE COLLEGE. THE VALUE OF THE FINAL PAYOUT FOR CALENDAR YEAR 2017 IS INCLUDED IN THE OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION IN SCHEDULE J COLUMN B (III). THE COLLEGE HAS IN PLACE A NON-QUALIFIED DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN FOR THE PRESIDENT, EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT AND A HEAD COACH. THE ANNUAL ACCRUALS FOR THESE BENEFITS HAVE BEEN REPORTED DESPITE BEING SUBJECT TO A SUBSTANTIAL RISK OF FORFEITURE AND CONTINGENT UPON THE EXECUTIVE'S CONTINUED EMPLOYMENT AT THE COLLEGE. THE VALUE OF THE ACCRUAL FOR CALENDAR YEAR 2017 IS INCLUDED IN THE DEFERRED COMPENSATION COLUMN (COLUMN C) OF SCHEDULE J.

NON-FIXED PAYMENTS ANNUALLY, PAY AWARDS WERE GIVEN IN RECOGNITION OF EMPLOYEES CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE OVERALL SUCCESS OF THE COLLEGE. ANY VARIABLE PAY AWARDS IN FUTURE YEARS WILL BE CONTINGENT ON INDIVIDUAL PERFORMANCE AND THE CONTINUED SUCCESS OF THE COLLEGE.

FIRST CLASS TRAVEL: PURSUANT TO A WRITTEN POLICY AND APPROPRIATE APPROVAL, FIRST CLASS TRAVEL IS PERMITTED TO CERTAIN OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES. TRAVEL FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES IS NOT INCLUDED IN TAXABLE WAGES. FIVE OFFICERS AND ONE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII FLEW FIRST CLASS DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2017. TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: PURSUANT TO A WRITTEN POLICY, CERTAIN OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES' SPOUSES ARE PERMITTED TO TRAVEL ON OCCASION WHEN NECESSARY FOR BUSINESS PURPOSE. SIX OFFICERS AND ONE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII WERE PROVIDED WITH COMPANION TRAVEL FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2017. GROSS-UP PAYMENT: PEPPERDINE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES GROSS-UP PAYMENTS TO EMPLOYEES THAT PROVIDE LATE SUBSTANTIATION OF EXPENSES UNDER ACCOUNTABLE PLAN RULES FOR ORDINARY AND NECESSARY BUSINESS EXPENSES. AS PART OF THE MINISTERIAL HOUSING PROGRAM, PEPPERDINE PROVIDED ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION TO PARTICIPANTS FOR WAGE WITHHOLDING IN AN AMOUNT EQUAL TO THE EMPLOYER'S SHARE OF THE PARTICIPANTS' SELF-EMPLOYMENT TAX. THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII THAT WERE PROVIDED WITH GROSS-UP PAYMENTS DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2017 INCLUDE THREE OFFICERS, FOUR KEY EMPLOYEES AND ONE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE. HOUSING: INCLUDED IN NON-TAXABLE BENEFITS OF EMPLOYEES WHO ARE MINISTERS IS THE VALUE OF A HOUSING ALLOWANCE PROVIDED BY PEPPERDINE UNIVERSITY TO MINISTERS. THE PROVISION OF MINISTERIAL HOUSING IS SUBJECT TO EXECUTIVE APPROVAL. THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII WHO WERE PROVIDED WITH MINISTERIAL HOUSING DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2017 INCLUDE THREE OFFICERS AND THREE KEY EMPLOYEES. HOUSING IS PROVIDED FOR FOUR OFFICERS DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2017 AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER AND IS NOT INCLUDED IN TAXABLE WAGES. HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUBS: THREE OFFICERS LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII RECEIVED REIMBURSEMENTS FOR EXPENDITURES ASSOCIATED WITH HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB MEMBERSHIPS. ALL EXPENDITURES ARE FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES AND ARE APPROVED PURSUANT TO THE UNIVERSITY'S REIMBURSEMENT POLICIES. PERSONAL SERVICE: DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2017, ONE OFFICER WAS PROVIDED CERTAIN HOUSE CLEANING SERVICES AND ONE OFFICER WAS PROVIDED APPLIANCE REPAIR SERVICES IN CONNECTION WITH THEIR OCCUPANCY OF ON-CAMPUS HOUSING. THREE OFFICERS AND ONE KEY EMPLOYEE WERE PROVIDED CHAUFFEUR / CAR SERVICES FOR BUSINESS RELATED TRANSPORTATION. THE PROVISION OF SUCH SERVICES IS NOT INCLUDED AS TAXABLE WAGES.

PEPPERDINE UNIVERSITY HAS AN INCENTIVE COMPENSATION PLAN FOR CERTAIN KEY EXECUTIVES. UNDER THE PLAN, UPON ACHIEVEMENT OF CERTAIN EXPECTATIONS AND GOALS AND AT THE DISCRETION OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS, THE PARTICIPANT WILL RECEIVE A UNIVERSITY CONTRIBUTION TO THE PLAN FOR THAT PLAN YEAR. UNIVERSITY CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE PLAN BECOME GRADUALLY VESTED BEGINNING WITH THE LAST DAY OF THE 3RD PLAN YEAR FOLLOWING THE CONTRIBUTION AND VEST 100% AT THE COMPLETION OF THE 7TH PLAN YEAR FOLLOWING THE AWARD. WHEN THE EMPLOYEE HAS ATTAINED AGE 62, THE ACCOUNT FULLY VESTS AND 100% IS PAID OUT TO THE EMPLOYEE. THE VESTING SCHEDULE IS THEN ACCELERATED SUCH THAT THE EMPLOYEE IS FULLY VESTED AFTER AGE 62. THE FOLLOWING AMOUNTS WERE AWARDED IN CALENDAR YEAR 2017: ANDREW K. BENTON - $105,536 GARY HANSON - $83,787 SAMUEL HINKLE - $47,788 RICK MARRS - $80,438 CHARLES PIPPIN - $86,428 THE FOLLOWING AMOUNTS WERE VESTED AND INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYEE'S COMPENSATION IN 2017: ANDREW K. BENTON - $102,120 PAUL B. LASITER - $63,276 SAMUEL HINKLE - $61,527 RICK MARRS - $74,129 CHARLES PIPPIN - $53,703 UNDER A NONQUALIFIED SUPPLEMENTAL RETIREMENT PLAN, SUBJECT TO THE PERFORMANCE OF FUTURE SERVICES AND OTHER CONDITIONS, PRESIDENT BENTON IS ENTITLED TO RECEIVE COMPENSATION OF APPROXIMATELY ONE YEAR'S SALARY AS THE RESULT OF THE COMPLETION OF FOUR YEARS OF SERVICE IN HIS EMPLOYMENT AS PRESIDENT OF PEPPERDINE IN 2019.

FORM 990, SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (F) CERTAIN AMOUNTS INCLUDED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN B(III), WERE PREVIOUSLY REPORTED ON THE PRIOR YEAR'S FORM 990, AS AMOUNTS AWARDED UNDER THE INCENTIVE COMPENSATION PLAN DISCLOSED IN RESPONSE TO SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 4B.

THE PRESIDENT RECEIVED OCCASIONAL FIRST CLASS TRAVEL (DEPENDING ON DISTANCE AND PRICING), A HOUSING ALLOWANCE AND HEALTH CLUB DUES . THE HOUSING ALLOWANCE AND FIRST CLASS TRAVEL ARE TREATED AS NONTAXABLE BENEFITS AND REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN D. IN ADDITION, THE COLLEGE PAID HEALTH CLUB DUES FOR THE PRESIDENT WHICH IS INCLUDED IN HIS W-2 AND REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN B (III).

PART I, LINE 1A HOUSING ALLOWANCE: THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED TO LIVE ON CAMPUS IN THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT AND, THEREFORE, THE HOUSING ALLOWANCE IS NOT TAXABLE. THE AMOUNT IS INCLUDED IN COLUMN D OF SCHEDULE J, PART II. SOCIAL CLUB MEMBERSHIP FEE: THE PRESIDENT'S MEMBERSHIP FEE TO YALE CLUB OF NEW YORK IS COVERED FOR THE PURPOSES OF CONDUCTING COLLEGE-RELATED BUSINESS. PERSONAL SERVICES: A COLLEGE EMPLOYEE PREPARES MEALS AT THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE COLLEGE. A COLLEGE EMPLOYEE FROM ITS FACILITIES MAINTENANCE DEPARTMENT IS ASSIGNED TO THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE. THE HOME IS MAINTAINED SIMILARLY TO OTHER CAMPUS FACILITIES. IN ADDITION TO CLEANING AND MAINTAINING THE PUBLIC AREAS OF THE RESIDENCE, THE INDIVIDUAL PERFORMS A SMALL AMOUNT OF HOUSEKEEPING IN THE PRESIDENT'S PERSONAL QUARTERS. THIS HOUSEKEEPING IS CONSIDERED TO BE OF NO ADDITIONAL COST TO THE INSTITUTION. A COLLEGE CAR AND DRIVER ARE PROVIDED WHEN TRAVELING ON COLLEGE BUSINESS. THESE BENEFITS ARE NONTAXABLE. THE PRESIDENT REIMBURSES THE COLLEGE FOR ANY NON-BUSINESS USE OF THE CAR AND DRIVER DURING THE YEAR.

PART I, LINE 7 THE COLLEGE DEDICATES A SMALL AMOUNT OF A BONUS POOL TO EACH MEMBER OF THE PRESIDENT'S CABINET TO AWARD WITHIN THEIR DIVISIONS. BONUSES ARE NOT CONTRACTUALLY BASED ON METRICS SUCH AS SALES, BUT ACKNOWLEDGE EXTRA EFFORT OR COMPLETION OF PROJECTS AND ARE AWARDED AFTER-THE-FACT.

THE PRESIDENT OF THE COLLEGE IS REQUIRED TO LIVE ON CAMPUS AS A CONDITION OF HIS EMPLOYMENT. CUSTODIAL CARE IS PROVIDED AT HIS RESIDENCE. MONMOUTH COUNTRY CLUB DUES ARE PAID BY THE COLLEGE FOR OUR VP OF DEVELOPMENT AND COLLEGE RELATIONS.
KEY EMPLOYEE - $76,500

ExplntnTxt: DETAIL REGARDING OTHER BENEFITS PROVIDED THE COLLEGE PROVIDES LODGING AND HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES TO THE PRESIDENT FOR THE BETTER PERFORMANCE OF HER DUTIES. IT IS CUSTOMARY FOR EMPLOYERS TO PROVIDE LODGING TO EMPLOYEES, SUCH AS THE PRESIDENT. THE VALUE OF THE PRESIDENT'S PERSONAL USE OF ANY LODGING AND HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES IS INCLUDED ON FORM 990, SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN D.

GROSS UP FOR COMPANY AUTO BENEFIT FOR DR. PETER TEAGUE. DR. PETER TEAGUE LIVES IN A COLLEGE OWNED RESIDENCE. THE VALUE OF THIS BENEFIT IS APPROXIMATELY $33,000 PER YEAR. THIS IS ADDED TO PART VII, SECTION A.
THERE IS NO POLICY FOR PAYMENTS OR REIMBURSEMENTS OF EXPENSES. THEY MUST BE REASONABLE TO BE CONSIDERED ACCEPTABLE EXPENSES.

THE PRESIDENT IS PROVIDED A RESIDENCE OF A CAMPUS HOUSE FROM THE UNIVERSITY AS PART OF THE EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT. THE RESIDENCE IS A REQUIREMENT FOR THE PRESIDENT POSITION. THE BENEFIT FROM THE PERSONAL USE OF THE PROVIDED HOUSING IS CONSIDERED NONTAXABLE WAGES AS IT IS PROVIDED FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY. USE OF FIRST CLASS AIR TRAVEL IS AVAILABLE TO THE PRESIDENT. SPOUSAL TRAVEL IS INCLUDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S TAXABLE INCOME.

FIRST-CLASS OR CHARTER TRAVEL HAS BEEN APPROVED FOR THE PRESIDENT AND HIS SPOUSE BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES AND AS STATED IN THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT. CABINET MEMBERS AND OTHER EMPLOYEES MAY TRAVEL FIRST-CLASS, BASED ON CERTAIN CONDITIONS, AS PER THE UNIVERSITYS TRAVEL POLICY. PREAPPROVAL OF FIRST-CLASS OR CHARTER TRAVEL IS REQUIRED BY THE EMPLOYEES SENIOR LEADERSHIP AND THE SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT AND CFO OR PRESIDENT. TRAVEL FOR SPOUSE/COMPANION A SPOUSE/COMPANION OF CABINET MEMBERS, TRUSTEES, AND OTHER EMPLOYEES OF THE UNIVERSITY MAY TRAVEL TO FUNCTIONS OR OTHER EVENTS RELATED TO THE ONGOING BUSINESS OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY WILL REIMBURSE FOR SPOUSE/COMPANION TRAVEL ONLY WHEN THERE IS A BONA FIDE BUSINESS PURPOSE FOR THE PRESENCE OF THE SPOUSE/COMPANION. ALL SPOUSE/COMPANION TRAVEL TO BE REIMBURSED MUST BE PREAPPROVED BY AN INDIVIDUAL IN THE EMPLOYEE'S SUPERVISORY CHAIN WHO IS A SENIOR LEADER AND BY THE SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT AND CFO. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE - HOUSING ALLOWANCE IS PROVIDED TO THE PRESIDENT AS APPROVED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES AND STATED IN THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT. HOUSING IS PROVIDED TO A KEY EMPLOYEE. THE HOUSING IS FURNISHED ON THE BUSINESS PREMISES OF THE UNIVERSITY, AT THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY, AND THE EMPLOYEE IS REQUIRED TO ACCEPT SUCH LODGING AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT. HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES OR INITIATION FEES - DUES FOR THE PRESIDENT AS APPROVED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES AND STATED IN THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT FOR BUSINESS AND FUNDRAISING PURPOSES.

NONFIXED PAYMENTS SELECT PERSONS LISTED ON FORM 990, PART VII, SECTION A, LINE 1, RECEIVED AN ADDITIONAL PERFORMANCE BASED BONUS. ADDITIONALLY, ALL REFERENCED EMPLOYEES RECEIVE A SMALL HOLIDAY BONUS IN THE SAME AMOUNT AS ALL UNIVERSITY EMPLOYEES RECEIVE.

Housing allowance provided to the President and to the VP/CBO in accordance with IRS guidelines. Pursuant to Internal Revenue Code Section 107, ministerial housing allowances are provided for qualifying ministerial employees. This is not included in taxable compensation. The President and VP/CBO met the qualifications for and received a ministerial housing allowance during the tax year.

Annually a salary survey from peer institutions is presented to the Compensation Committee of the Board who determines the President's salary. The President uses the same survey to determine other Officer's and key employee's salaries and communicates compensation decision to the Board Compensation Committee.
